statistics |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot =|author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }}'''Frederic John Mouat''' (18 May 1816–12 Jan 1897) was a British surgeon. He was born in [[Maidstone]], Kent, the son of an army surgeon, and trained at [[University College London]] and [[Edinburgh University]], qualifying as a Member of the [[Royal College of Surgeons]] in 1838. He entered the [[Indian Medical Service]] and was posted Assistant-Surgeon in [[Bengal]] in 1840. In 1853 he became Surgeon, in 1860 Surgeon-Major and ultimately Deputy Inspector-General of Hospitals. He was also Professor of Medicine in the [[Bengal Medical College]]. He spent 30 years in India, where he was a leading figure in the field of education, in which he was a major campaigner to establish the first universities in India and [[prison reform]], including holding the post of Inspector-General of Gaols in lower Bengal. In 1857, during the [[Indian Mutiny]], he was asked to investigate the [[Andaman Islands]] as a potential [[penal colony]]. He subsequently published a book about his Andaman experiences: ''Adventures and researches among the Andaman islanders'' (1863).{{cite journal|title = Obituary|journal = British Medical Journal|accessdate = 6 August 2010|pmc=2433148|page=628|volume=1|issue=1888}} He retired to the UK in 1870 and started a new career as an Inspector for the Local Government Board. He was also an active member of the [[Royal Statistical Society]], becoming its President in 1890.{{cite web|url = http://www.rss.org.uk/site/cms/contentviewarticle.asp?article=486|title = Royal Statistical Society Presidents|publisher= Royal Statistical Society|accessdate = 6 August 2010}} He died in 1897 and was cremated at Woking. He left a widow and four stepchildren.
